oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Impact of soil management practices on soil fertility and disease suppressiveness
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Tamm, Lucius
Bruns, Christian
Leifert, Carlo
Fuchs, Jacques G.
Thürig, Barbara
Specht, Nicole
Fliessbach, Andreas
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Crop health, quality, protection
Crop combinations and interactions
Soil biology
Soil quality
Soil tillage
Composting and manuring
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Soil management practices are targeted to provide adequate crop nutrition and to ensure durable soil fertility and to avoid negative environmental impacts. Soil management also aims to reduce pest and disease pressure on crops. Organic farming is believed to increase soil suppressiveness towards soil-borne diseases as well aerial diseases. In this paper we will discuss the potential of soil manage-ment as a tool to improve disease suppressiveness in practice.
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Tamm, Lucius; Bruns, Christian; Leifert, Carlo; Fuchs, Jacques G.; Thürig, Barbara; Specht, Nicole and Fliessbach, Andreas (2006) Impact of soil management practices on soil fertility and disease suppressiveness. Paper at: Joint Organic Congress, Odense, Denmark, May 30-31, 2006.
